questions.question_text_1: Consider the following graph. A triangle-free subset of seven vertices is highlighted. Find the size of the largest triangle-free subset of vertices in this graph.
questions.question_text_2: Consider the following graph. A triangle-free subset of seven vertices is highlighted. Find the size of the largest triangle-free subset of vertices in this graph.

questions.question_text_1: The TRIANGLE-FREEDOM problem is the following: the input is a simple undirected graph G and a positive integer k. An instance (G, k) is a YES-instance if and only if G has a subset S of at least k vertices that are triangle-free. What can you say about TRIANGLE-FREEDOM? Check all that apply.
question_texts: The TRIANGLE-FREEDOM problem is the following: the input is a simple undirected graph G and a positive integer k. An instance (G, k) is a YES-instance if and only if G has a subset S of at least k vertices that are triangle-free. What can you say about TRIANGLE-FREEDOM? Check all that apply.

options.option_text: Finding a Hamiltonian cycle in a graph is as hard as determining the answer tothe Marbles Elimination question; i.e, there is a reduction from the problem of Marbles Elimination to the problem of finding a Hamiltonian cycle.

Determining the answer to the Marbles Elimination question is as hard asfinding a Hamiltonian cycle in a graph; i.e, there is a reduction from the Hamiltonian cycle problem to the problem of Marbles Elimination.
Marbles Elimination is in P by a reduction to the Max Flow problem.
Yes, this is a valid set of constraints.
No, the sum in the objective function should be taken only over neighbors ofu.
No, the sum in the second constraint should be taken only over in-neighborsof v and out-neighbors of v, respectively.

questions.question_text_1: Recall that the size of an optimal vertex cover is at most twice the size of a maximum matching of a graph G. Are there examples of graphs where the size of the optimal vertex cover is exactly equal to twice the size of its maximum matching? For example, this is not true for a path on three vertices: the size of both the maximum matching and minimum vertex cover is 1.
question_texts: Recall that the size of an optimal vertex cover is at most twice the size of a maximum matching of a graph G. Are there examples of graphs where the size of the optimal vertex cover is exactly equal to twice the size of its maximum matching? For example, this is not true for a path on three vertices: the size of both the maximum matching and minimum vertex cover is 1.
